metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: All JavaScript objects inherit properties and methods from a prototype.
content.html: All JavaScript objects inherit properties and methods from a prototype.

content.text: In the previous chapter we learned how to use an object constructor :
content.html: In the previous chapter we learned how to use an object constructor:

content.code_html:
function Person(first, last, age, eyecolor) {
  this.firstName = first;
  this.lastName = last;
  this.age = age;
  this.eyeColor = eyecolor;
}

const myFather = new Person("John", "Doe", 50, "blue");
const myMother = new Person("Sally", "Rally", 48, "green");

content.text: We also learned that you can not add a new property to an existing object constructor:
content.html: We also learned that you can not add a new property to an existing object constructor:

content.code_html: Person.nationality = "English";

content.text: To add a new property to a constructor, you must add it to the constructor function:
content.html: To add a new property to a constructor, you must add it to the constructor function:

content.code_html:
function Person(first, last, age, eyecolor) {
  this.firstName = first;
  this.lastName = last;
  this.age = age;
  this.eyeColor = eyecolor;
  this.nationality = "English";
}

content.text: All JavaScript objects inherit properties and methods from a prototype:
content.html: All JavaScript objects inherit properties and methods from a prototype:

content.text: The Object.prototype is on the top of the prototype inheritance chain:
content.html: The Object.prototype is on the top of the prototype inheritance chain:

content.text: Date objects, Array objects, and Person objects inherit from Object.prototype .
content.html: Date objects, Array objects, and Person objects inherit from Object.prototype.

content.text: Adding Properties and Methods to Objects
Sometimes you want to add new properties (or methods) to all existing objects of a given type.
content.html: Sometimes you want to add new properties (or methods) to all existing objects of a given type.

content.text: Sometimes you want to add new properties (or methods) to an object constructor.
content.html: Sometimes you want to add new properties (or methods) to an object constructor.

content.text: The JavaScript prototype property allows you to add new properties to object constructors:
content.html: The JavaScript prototype property allows you to add new properties to object constructors:

content.code_html:
function Person(first, last, age, eyecolor) {
  this.firstName = first;
  this.lastName = last;
  this.age = age;
  this.eyeColor = eyecolor;
}

Person.prototype.nationality = "English";

content.text: The JavaScript prototype property also allows you to add new methods to objects constructors:
content.html: The JavaScript prototype property also allows you to add new methods to objects constructors:

content.code_html:
function Person(first, last, age, eyecolor) {
  this.firstName = first;
  this.lastName = last;
  this.age = age;
  this.eyeColor = eyecolor;
}

Person.prototype.name = function() {
  return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
};

content.text: Only modify your own prototypes. Never modify the prototypes of standard JavaScript objects.
content.html: Only modify your own prototypes. Never modify the prototypes of standard JavaScript objects.
